topics.title: Early Facebook grind and startup reality
topics.summary: Boz describes the intense early Facebook years: extreme hours, no support functions, building/racking servers, and the unglamorous reality behind startup “romance.” He emphasizes survivorship bias and the real sacrifices that don’t always pay off.

topics.title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
topics.summary: Boz caveats that he wasn’t a founder, then explains how modern mentorship ecosystems (podcasts/newsletters) fill a gap left by traditional professional institutions. He notes founders face similar challenges at different scales and encourages learning from shared experience.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Boz’s background and impact at Meta: early engineer, News Feed, mobile ads, messaging, and leading Reality Labs/AR-VR hardware. He previews major topics for the conversation.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Vanta (trust/compliance automation) and Eppo (A/B testing and feature management).

topics.title: Boz fun facts and prom story
topics.summary: Lenny runs through unusual Boz trivia; Boz clarifies the Taekwondo detail and tells how 4-H conferences and dancing led to attending 14 proms, including three in one weekend.

topics.title: Leverage your manager more directly
topics.summary: Boz explains why people avoid asking for help and why it’s a mistake: the job is to get outcomes, not prove independence. He shares how managers can unblock, prevent miscommunication, and why leaders are incentivized to help you succeed.

topics.title: Practical tactics for asking for help
topics.summary: Boz recommends lightweight written updates (“no response required”), clear framing of blockers, and drafting emails/questions to make it cheap for leaders to assist. He describes leadership as “spinning plates” via many small touches.

topics.title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
topics.summary: They discuss Meta’s open information culture, including the downside of leaks and why Boz sees leaks as a trust violation. Boz argues transparency maximizes talent leverage but requires strong personal systems to find signal amid noise.

topics.title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
topics.summary: Boz challenges the simplistic “bottom-up” narrative: big directions are often top-down from Zuck, but teams have degrees of freedom within guardrails. He stresses clarity on where leaders are prescriptive vs where teams can explore.

topics.title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
topics.summary: Examples of deep involvement include Zuck whiteboarding News Feed UI details and later diving into ranking modernization; Boz cites pushing hand tracking and mixed reality into headsets despite skepticism. They discuss when execs should be in the weeds based on what’s truly pivotal.

topics.title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
topics.summary: Boz explains the News Feed controversy: users complained but usage doubled, revealing preference vs stated preference. He notes the real lesson isn’t “ignore customers,” but distinguish between a correct core idea and fixable execution mistakes (e.g., over-broadcasting).

topics.title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
topics.summary: Boz reflects on how passion drives productivity and how he learned he can become passionate about new areas (ads, hardware) despite initial resistance. He advises giving new roles time to click while recognizing some work will never fit.

topics.title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
topics.summary: Boz describes rotating roles every ~6 months early on to maximize learning, then accelerating after finding deep learning-rich roles (ads, current hardware org). He recommends early-career experimentation, compounding skills, and avoiding becoming stuck as an exhausted domain specialist.
